name: Hydrogen
uses: Used in ammonia production, petroleum refining, and as a rocket fuel
funFact: Hydrogen is the most abundant element in the universe, making up about 75% of its elemental mass.

name: Helium
discovery: 1868 by Pierre Janssen and Norman Lockyer
uses: Used in cryogenics, deep-sea breathing systems, and as a lifting gas for balloons
funFact: Helium is the only element that cannot be solidified by cooling at standard pressure.

name: Lithium
uses: Used in batteries, mood-stabilizing drugs, and heat-resistant glass
funFact: Lithium is so light it can float on water, and it's the least dense solid element.

name: Beryllium
uses: Used in X-ray windows, spacecraft, and nuclear reactors
funFact: Beryllium is transparent to X-rays, which is why it's used in X-ray windows.

name: Boron
discovery: 1808 by Humphry Davy, Joseph Louis Gay-Lussac, and Louis Jacques Thénard
uses: Used in fiberglass, detergents, and as a semiconductor dopant
funFact: Boron compounds have been known for thousands of years, but the pure element wasn't isolated until 1808.

name: Carbon
uses: Used in all organic life, steel production, and as graphite in pencils
funFact: Carbon has the highest melting/sublimation point of all elements.

name: Nitrogen
uses: Used in fertilizers, explosives, and as an inert atmosphere
funFact: Nitrogen makes up about 78% of Earth's atmosphere by volume.

name: Oxygen
discovery: 1774 by Joseph Priestley and Carl Wilhelm Scheele
uses: Essential for respiration, used in steel production and medicine
funFact: Oxygen is the third-most abundant element in the universe.

name: Fluorine
uses: Used in toothpaste, refrigerants, and uranium processing
funFact: Fluorine is the most reactive and electronegative of all elements.

name: Neon
discovery: 1898 by William Ramsay and Morris Travers
uses: Used in neon signs, cryogenic refrigeration, and lasers
funFact: Neon gives off a bright reddish-orange light when used in discharge tubes.

name: Sodium
uses: Used in table salt, street lighting, and as a heat transfer agent
funFact: Sodium is so reactive it must be stored in oil to prevent reaction with air.

name: Magnesium
uses: Used in lightweight alloys, flares, and as a dietary supplement
funFact: Magnesium burns with a brilliant white light, which is why it's used in flares.

name: Aluminum
uses: Used in cans, foil, aircraft, and construction
funFact: Aluminum was once more valuable than gold due to the difficulty in extracting it.

name: Silicon
uses: Used in computer chips, solar cells, and glass
funFact: Silicon makes up about 28% of the Earth's crust by mass.

name: Phosphorus
uses: Used in fertilizers, detergents, and matches
funFact: Phosphorus was discovered from urine, where it's found in considerable quantities.

name: Sulfur
uses: Used in gunpowder, rubber vulcanization, and fertilizers
funFact: Sulfur burns with a blue flame and produces sulfur dioxide, which has a pungent smell.

name: Chlorine
uses: Used in water purification, PVC, and disinfectants
funFact: Chlorine gas was used as a chemical weapon during World War I.

name: Argon
discovery: 1894 by Lord Rayleigh and William Ramsay
uses: Used in lighting, welding, and as an inert atmosphere
funFact: Argon is the most abundant noble gas in Earth's atmosphere.

name: Potassium
uses: Used in fertilizers, soaps, and as a dietary supplement
funFact: Potassium is so reactive with water that it must be stored under oil.

name: Calcium
uses: Used in bones, teeth, cement, and as a dietary supplement
funFact: Calcium is the fifth most abundant element in the Earth's crust.

name: Scandium
uses: Used in aluminum alloys, sports equipment, and high-intensity lights
funFact: Scandium is more common on the Moon than on Earth.

name: Titanium
uses: Used in aircraft, medical implants, and paint pigments
funFact: Titanium is as strong as steel but 45% lighter.

name: Vanadium
uses: Used in steel alloys, tools, and as a catalyst
funFact: Vanadium was discovered twice, first in 1801 and then again in 1830.

name: Chromium
uses: Used in stainless steel, chrome plating, and dyes
funFact: Chromium gives rubies their red color and emeralds their green.

name: Manganese
uses: Used in steel production, batteries, and fertilizers
funFact: Manganese is essential for all known living organisms.

name: Iron
uses: Used in steel, magnets, and hemoglobin in blood
funFact: Iron is the most abundant element (by mass) in the Earth as a whole.

name: Cobalt
uses: Used in magnets, batteries, and blue pigments
funFact: Cobalt is named after the German word for goblin (kobold), as miners thought it was evil.

name: Nickel
uses: Used in coins, stainless steel, and batteries
funFact: Nickel is the main component of meteorites that are naturally occurring alloys.

name: Copper
uses: Used in electrical wiring, plumbing, and coins
funFact: Copper has been used by humans for at least 10,000 years.

name: Zinc
uses: Used in galvanization, brass, and dietary supplements
funFact: Zinc is essential for all living things and is the second most abundant trace metal in humans after iron.

name: Gallium
uses: Used in semiconductors, LEDs, and thermometers
funFact: Gallium melts in your hand, with a melting point of 29.76°C (85.57°F).

name: Germanium
uses: Used in fiber optics, infrared optics, and semiconductors
funFact: Germanium was one of the elements predicted by Mendeleev before its discovery.

name: Arsenic
uses: Used in pesticides, semiconductors, and wood preservatives
funFact: Arsenic has been called "the king of poisons and the poison of kings".

name: Selenium
uses: Used in photocopiers, glass production, and dietary supplements
funFact: Selenium is named after the Greek word for the Moon (Selene).

name: Bromine
uses: Used in flame retardants, photography, and water purification
funFact: Bromine is one of only two liquid elements at room temperature.

name: Krypton
discovery: 1898 by William Ramsay and Morris Travers
uses: Used in lighting, photography, and lasers
funFact: Krypton is used in some high-powered flashlight bulbs to produce a very bright white light.

name: Rubidium
discovery: 1861 by Robert Bunsen and Gustav Kirchhoff
uses: Used in atomic clocks, photocells, and as a catalyst
funFact: Rubidium can spontaneously ignite when exposed to air.

name: Strontium
uses: Used in fireworks, flares, and toothpaste for sensitive teeth
funFact: Strontium salts give fireworks their red color.

name: Yttrium
uses: Used in LEDs, superconductors, and camera lenses
funFact: Yttrium is named after the village of Ytterby in Sweden, where its mineral was first discovered.

name: Zirconium
uses: Used in nuclear reactors, jewelry, and ceramics
funFact: Zirconium is highly resistant to corrosion, even by strong acids and alkalis.

name: Niobium
uses: Used in jet engines, superconducting magnets, and jewelry
funFact: Niobium was originally called columbium, after Columbia (a poetic name for America).

name: Molybdenum
uses: Used in steel alloys, lubricants, and plant fertilizers
funFact: Molybdenum has one of the highest melting points of all pure elements.

name: Technetium
discovery: 1937 by Carlo Perrier and Emilio Segrè
uses: Used in medical imaging and as a corrosion inhibitor
funFact: Technetium was the first artificially produced element and is the lightest radioactive element.

name: Ruthenium
uses: Used in electrical contacts, wear-resistant alloys, and jewelry
funFact: Ruthenium is part of the platinum group metals and is extremely rare.

name: Rhodium
uses: Used in catalytic converters, jewelry plating, and electrical contacts
funFact: Rhodium is the most expensive precious metal, even more so than gold or platinum.

name: Palladium
uses: Used in catalytic converters, jewelry, and hydrogen purification
funFact: Palladium can absorb up to 900 times its own volume of hydrogen at room temperature.

name: Silver
uses: Used in jewelry, photography, and electrical contacts
funFact: Silver has the highest electrical conductivity of any element.

name: Cadmium
discovery: 1817 by Friedrich Stromeyer and Karl Samuel Leberecht Hermann
uses: Used in batteries, pigments, and nuclear reactors
funFact: Cadmium is highly toxic and was responsible for the itai-itai disease in Japan.

name: Indium
discovery: 1863 by Ferdinand Reich and Hieronymous Theodor Richter
uses: Used in LCD screens, solders, and semiconductors
funFact: Indium is named for the indigo blue line in its spectrum.

name: Tin
uses: Used in cans, solder, and bronze alloys
funFact: Tin has two allotropes: white tin (metallic) and gray tin (nonmetallic).

name: Antimony
uses: Used in flame retardants, batteries, and alloys
funFact: Antimony was used in ancient Egypt as a cosmetic for eye makeup.

name: Tellurium
uses: Used in solar panels, thermoelectric devices, and alloys
funFact: Tellurium is one of the rarest stable solid elements in Earth's crust.

name: Iodine
uses: Used in disinfectants, dietary supplements, and photography
funFact: Iodine is essential for thyroid function in humans.

name: Xenon
discovery: 1898 by William Ramsay and Morris Travers
uses: Used in lighting, anesthesia, and ion propulsion engines
funFact: Xenon is used in high-intensity discharge lamps for movie projectors and car headlights.

name: Cesium
discovery: 1860 by Robert Bunsen and Gustav Kirchhoff
uses: Used in atomic clocks, drilling fluids, and photoelectric cells
funFact: Cesium is the most reactive metal and the least electronegative element.

name: Barium
uses: Used in medical imaging, fireworks, and glass production
funFact: Barium compounds are highly poisonous, yet barium sulfate is safe enough to be used in medical imaging.

name: Lanthanum
uses: Used in camera lenses, battery electrodes, and hydrogen storage
funFact: Lanthanum gives its name to the entire lanthanide series.

name: Cerium
discovery: 1803 by Jöns Jacob Berzelius and Wilhelm Hisinger
uses: Used in self-cleaning ovens, catalytic converters, and lighter flints
funFact: Cerium is the most abundant of the rare earth elements.

name: Praseodymium
uses: Used in aircraft engines, studio lighting, and colored glass
funFact: Praseodymium is used to make didymium glass, which protects welders' eyes.

name: Neodymium
uses: Used in powerful magnets, lasers, and colored glass
funFact: Neodymium magnets are the strongest permanent magnets known.

name: Promethium
discovery: 1945 by Jacob A. Marinsky, Lawrence E. Glendenin, and Charles D. Coryell
uses: Used in nuclear batteries and luminous paint
funFact: Promethium is the only rare earth radioactive metal.

name: Samarium
uses: Used in magnets, cancer treatment, and nuclear reactors
funFact: Samarium was named after the mineral samarskite, which in turn was named after a Russian mine official.

name: Europium
uses: Used in phosphors for TVs and fluorescent lamps
funFact: Europium is the most reactive rare earth element.

name: Gadolinium
discovery: 1880 by Jean Charles Galissard de Marignac
uses: Used in MRI contrast agents, nuclear reactors, and data storage
funFact: Gadolinium has the highest neutron absorption cross-section of any known element.

name: Terbium
uses: Used in solid-state devices, fuel cells, and fluorescent lamps
funFact: Terbium is used in the green phosphors in color TV tubes.

name: Dysprosium
uses: Used in lasers, nuclear reactors, and data storage
funFact: Dysprosium's name comes from the Greek word 'dysprositos', meaning 'hard to get'.

name: Holmium
discovery: 1878 by Jacques-Louis Soret and Marc Delafontaine
uses: Used in nuclear control rods, lasers, and colorants for cubic zirconia
funFact: Holmium has the highest magnetic strength of any element.

name: Erbium
uses: Used in fiber optic cables, lasers, and nuclear technology
funFact: Erbium-doped optical fibers are crucial for long-distance communication.

name: Thulium
uses: Used in portable X-ray devices, lasers, and superconductors
funFact: Thulium is the rarest of the naturally occurring rare earth elements.

name: Ytterbium
discovery: 1878 by Jean Charles Galissard de Marignac
uses: Used in atomic clocks, stress gauges, and lasers
funFact: Ytterbium's atomic clock is the world's most precise.

name: Lutetium
discovery: 1907 by Georges Urbain and Carl Auer von Welsbach
uses: Used in PET scans, cancer treatment, and petroleum refining
funFact: Lutetium is the hardest and densest of the lanthanides.

name: Hafnium
discovery: 1923 by Dirk Coster and George de Hevesy
uses: Used in nuclear reactors, plasma torches, and microprocessors
funFact: Hafnium is named after Hafnia, the Latin name for Copenhagen.

name: Tantalum
uses: Used in electronic capacitors, surgical implants, and chemical equipment
funFact: Tantalum is named after Tantalus from Greek mythology due to its resistance to acids.

name: Tungsten
discovery: 1783 by Juan José and Fausto Elhuyar
uses: Used in light bulb filaments, cutting tools, and armor-piercing ammunition
funFact: Tungsten has the highest melting point of all metals (3422°C).

name: Rhenium
discovery: 1925 by Walter Noddack, Ida Tacke, and Otto Berg
uses: Used in jet engines, thermocouples, and catalysts
funFact: Rhenium was the last naturally occurring element to be discovered.

name: Osmium
uses: Used in fountain pen tips, electrical contacts, and instrument pivots
funFact: Osmium is the densest naturally occurring element.

name: Iridium
uses: Used in spark plugs, crucibles, and standard meter bars
funFact: Iridium is found in higher concentrations in meteorites than in Earth's crust.

name: Platinum
uses: Used in jewelry, catalytic converters, and laboratory equipment
funFact: Platinum is so rare that all the platinum ever mined would fit in an average-sized living room.

name: Gold
uses: Used in jewelry, electronics, and as a monetary standard
funFact: All of the gold ever mined would fit into a cube with sides of about 21 meters.

name: Mercury
uses: Used in thermometers, barometers, and fluorescent lights
funFact: Mercury is the only metal that is liquid at standard conditions for temperature and pressure.

name: Thallium
uses: Used in infrared detectors, low-temperature thermometers, and rodenticides
funFact: Thallium was used as a poison before its toxicity was fully understood.

name: Lead
uses: Used in batteries, radiation shielding, and construction
funFact: Lead was used by the Romans for plumbing, which is why its symbol is Pb (from plumbum).

name: Bismuth
uses: Used in cosmetics, pharmaceuticals, and low-melting alloys
funFact: Bismuth has the highest atomic mass of any non-radioactive element.

name: Polonium
uses: Used in antistatic devices and as a heat source in space satellites
funFact: Polonium is highly radioactive and was used to poison Alexander Litvinenko in 2006.

name: Astatine
discovery: 1940 by Dale R. Corson, Kenneth Ross MacKenzie, and Emilio Segrè
uses: Used in nuclear medicine and scientific research
funFact: Astatine is the rarest naturally occurring element on Earth.

name: Radon
uses: Used in cancer treatment and earthquake prediction
funFact: Radon is the heaviest known gas and is radioactive.

name: Francium
uses: Used in scientific research only
funFact: Francium is the second rarest naturally occurring element and the most unstable of the first 101 elements.

name: Radium
uses: Used in luminous paints and cancer treatment
funFact: Radium was once used in self-luminous paints for watches and aircraft instruments.

name: Actinium
uses: Used in neutron sources and cancer treatment
funFact: Actinium glows blue in the dark due to its intense radioactivity.

name: Thorium
uses: Used in nuclear reactors, gas mantles, and alloys
funFact: Thorium is about three times more abundant than uranium in Earth's crust.

name: Protactinium
discovery: 1913 by Kasimir Fajans and Oswald Helmuth Göhring
uses: Used in scientific research only
funFact: Protactinium is one of the rarest and most expensive naturally occurring elements.

name: Uranium
uses: Used in nuclear power plants and nuclear weapons
funFact: Uranium is about 40 times more abundant than silver in the Earth's crust.

name: Neptunium
discovery: 1940 by Edwin McMillan and Philip H. Abelson
uses: Used in neutron detection equipment
funFact: Neptunium was the first transuranium element to be discovered.

name: Plutonium
discovery: 1940 by Glenn T. Seaborg, Edwin McMillan, Joseph W. Kennedy, and Arthur Wahl
uses: Used in nuclear weapons and as a power source in space probes
funFact: Plutonium is named after the dwarf planet Pluto, continuing the naming convention of uranium and neptunium.

name: Americium
discovery: 1944 by Glenn T. Seaborg, Ralph A. James, Leon O. Morgan, and Albert Ghiorso
uses: Used in smoke detectors and neutron sources
funFact: Americium is the only synthetic element to have found its way into the household (in smoke detectors).

name: Curium
discovery: 1944 by Glenn T. Seaborg, Ralph A. James, and Albert Ghiorso
uses: Used in scientific research and as a power source in space probes
funFact: Curium is named after Marie and Pierre Curie, the pioneers in radioactivity research.

name: Berkelium
discovery: 1949 by Stanley G. Thompson, Albert Ghiorso, and Glenn T. Seaborg
uses: Used in scientific research only
funFact: Berkelium is named after Berkeley, California, where it was discovered.

name: Californium
discovery: 1950 by Stanley G. Thompson, Kenneth Street Jr., Albert Ghiorso, and Glenn T. Seaborg
uses: Used in neutron sources for metal detection and cancer treatment
funFact: Californium is one of the few transuranium elements with practical applications.

name: Einsteinium
uses: Used in scientific research only
funFact: Einsteinium was discovered in the debris of the first hydrogen bomb explosion.

name: Fermium
uses: Used in scientific research only
funFact: Fermium was discovered in the debris of the first hydrogen bomb explosion.

name: Mendelevium
discovery: 1955 by Albert Ghiorso, Bernard G. Harvey, Gregory R. Choppin, Stanley G. Thompson, and Glenn T. Seaborg
uses: Used in scientific research only
funFact: Mendelevium is named after Dmitri Mendeleev, the creator of the periodic table.

name: Nobelium
discovery: 1958 by Albert Ghiorso, Glenn T. Seaborg, Torbørn Sikkeland, and John R. Walton
uses: Used in scientific research only
funFact: Nobelium is named after Alfred Nobel, the founder of the Nobel Prizes.

name: Lawrencium
discovery: 1961 by Albert Ghiorso, Torbjørn Sikkeland, Almon E. Larsh, and Robert M. Latimer
uses: Used in scientific research only
funFact: Lawrencium is named after Ernest O. Lawrence, inventor of the cyclotron.

name: Rutherfordium
discovery: 1964 by Georgy Flerov and colleagues and independently by Albert Ghiorso and colleagues
uses: Used in scientific research only
funFact: Rutherfordium is named after Ernest Rutherford, the father of nuclear physics.

name: Dubnium
discovery: 1967 by Georgy Flerov and colleagues and independently by Albert Ghiorso and colleagues
uses: Used in scientific research only
funFact: Dubnium is named after Dubna, Russia, where the Joint Institute for Nuclear Research is located.

name: Seaborgium
uses: Used in scientific research only
funFact: Seaborgium is named after Glenn T. Seaborg, who was alive when the element was named (a rare honor).

name: Bohrium
discovery: 1981 by Peter Armbruster and Gottfried Münzenberg
uses: Used in scientific research only
funFact: Bohrium is named after Niels Bohr, the physicist who made foundational contributions to understanding atomic structure.

name: Hassium
discovery: 1984 by Peter Armbruster and Gottfried Münzenberg
uses: Used in scientific research only
funFact: Hassium is named after the German state of Hesse, where the discovery facility is located.

name: Meitnerium
discovery: 1982 by Peter Armbruster and Gottfried Münzenberg
uses: Used in scientific research only
funFact: Meitnerium is named after Lise Meitner, the physicist who first explained nuclear fission.

name: Darmstadtium
uses: Used in scientific research only
funFact: Darmstadtium is named after Darmstadt, Germany, where the element was discovered.

name: Roentgenium
uses: Used in scientific research only
funFact: Roentgenium is named after Wilhelm Röntgen, the discoverer of X-rays.

name: Copernicium
uses: Used in scientific research only
funFact: Copernicium is named after Nicolaus Copernicus, the astronomer who proposed the heliocentric model.

name: Nihonium
uses: Used in scientific research only
funFact: Nihonium is the first element named after a country in East Asia (Japan - 'Nihon' means Japan in Japanese).

name: Flerovium
uses: Used in scientific research only
funFact: Flerovium is named after the Flerov Laboratory of Nuclear Reactions, where many superheavy elements were synthesized.

name: Moscovium
uses: Used in scientific research only
funFact: Moscovium is named after the Moscow region, where the discovery facility is located.

name: Livermorium
uses: Used in scientific research only
funFact: Livermorium is named after the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California.

name: Tennessine
uses: Used in scientific research only
funFact: Tennessine is named after the state of Tennessee, where the Oak Ridge National Laboratory is located.

name: Oganesson
uses: Used in scientific research only
funFact: Oganesson is named after Yuri Oganessian, a pioneer in superheavy element research, and is the only element named after a living person (as of its naming).
